seriesStmt.title: Encyclopaedia Britannica: A machine-readable text transcription

bibl.title: Encyclopaedia Britannica: a dictionary of arts, sciences, and general literature

publisher.orgName: University of California Libraries, California Digital Library

listBibl.head: Alternate image sources for this edition:
listBibl.desc: Alternate images of the same print editions were substituted when the primary source had unusable images for those pages.
listBibl.bibl: Hathi Trust, from print source at the University of Michigan: vol. 14, pp. 34-35; vol. 15, pp. 170-171.

correction.p: This electronic text file was created by optical character recognition (OCR). OCR errors have not been corrected.
Illegible text in the original is indicated using unclear or gap, as appropriate. If corrected, the reference source is indicated with supplied.

normalization.p: Original spelling is preserved. When noticed, obvious misspellings are combined with the correct spelling as choice in the TEI. Ligatures are reproduced as multiple letters. Original footnote and marginal note sigla are replaced with sequential numbers for each entry.

punctuation.p: Extra space around punctuation marks is removed.

quotation.p: Quotation marks are retained as content in the text. Redundant open quotation marks at the start of lines inside block quotes are silently removed.

segmentation.p: The div type="entry" element divides the text into individual entries.
The div type="section" and div type="subsection" elements are reserved for future entry subsections.

list.item: Encoding uses the recommendations for Level 3 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines.
Individual entries and page-breaks are encoded, but column breaks are omitted.
Running headers and side descriptions are not included.
Some font formatting is preserved: italic, small caps, strike-through, subscript, superscript, underline. The following formatting is ignored: bold, font size, typeface.

projectDesc.p: All text was encoded for the Nineteenth-Century Knowledge Project to provide a machine-readable edition of the Encyclopedia Britannica to analyze.
Subject-level metadata was added to each entry using the HIVE automated vocabulary server created by the Metadata Research Center at Drexel University (https://hive2.cci.drexel.edu).

samplingDecl.p: The first release is a reproduction of text matter for all entries. It does not include images, tables, formulae, front- or back-matter. It omits volume 1, which consists of "Dissertations" rather than entries.

prefixDef.p: URIs with the prefix fast: point to terms in the OCLC FAST (Faceted Application of Subject Terminology) subject heading schema derived from the Library of Congress Subject Headings (LCSH).
URIs with the prefix lcsh1910: point to subject terms in the volume Subject Headings Used in the Dictionary Catalogues of the Library of Congress, 7 vols., Library of Congress, 1910.
URIs with the prefix ht: point to page images in the Hathi Trust.
URIs with the prefix ia: point to page images in the Internet Archive.
URIs with the prefix nls: point to page images in the National Library of Scotland.

div.p: ABBREVIATION, a letter or group of letters, taken from a word or words, and employed to represent them for the sake of brevity. Abbreviations, both of single words and of phrases, having a meaning more or less fixed and recognised, are common in ancient writings and inscriptions, and very many are in use at the present time. A distinction is to be observed between abbreviations and tho contractions that are frequently to be met with in old manuscripts, and even in early printed books, whereby letters are dropped out here and there, or particular collocations of letters represented by somewhat arbitrary symbols. The commonest form of abbreviation is the substitution for a word of its initial letter; but, with a view to prevent ambiguity, one or more of the other letters are frequently added. Letters are often doubled to indicate a plural or a superlative.

table.head: I. Classical Abbreviations. —The following list contains a selection from the abbreviations that occur in the writings and inscriptions of the Romans :—

row.cell: Absolvo, Aedilis, Aes, Ager, Ago, Aio, Amicus, Annus, Antiquo, Auctor, Auditor, Augustus, Aulus, Aurum, Aut.
Aes alienum, Ante audita, Apud agrum, Aurum argentum.

Auro argento aere flando feriundo.
Describing the function of the triumviri monetales.
Ante diem; e.g., A.D.V. Ante diem quintum.
A. L. Ae. and A. L. E.
Amico posuit monumentum, Annorum plus minus.
Aram votam volens dedicavit, Arma votiva dono dedit.
A tergo. Also A TE. and A TER.
Augusti (generally of two). AVGGG. Augusti tres.
Balbius, Balbus, Beatus, Bene, Beneficiarius, Beneficium, Bonus, Brutus, Bustum.
Bixit annos, Bonis auguriis, Bonus amabilis.
Bona femina, Bona fides, Bona fortuna, Bonum factum.
Bonum judicium. B. I.1. Boni judicis judicium.
Bona paterna, Bonorum potestas, Bonum publicum.
Bene vale, Bene vixit, Bonus vir.
Caesar, Caius, Caput, Causa, Censor, Civis, Cohors, Colonia, Comitialis (dies), Condemno, Consul, Cum, Curo, Custos.
Caia, Centuria, Cum, the prefix Con.
Civis bonus, Commune bonum, Conjugi benemerenti, Cui bono.
Calumniae causa, Causa cognita, Conjugi carissimae, Con silium cepit, Curiae consulto.
Caesar (or Caius) curavit faciendum, Caius Caii filius.
Caesaris decreto, Caius Decius, Comitialibus diebus.
Causa fiduciae, Conjugi fecit, Curavit faciendum.
Caius Julius, Consul jussit, Curavit judex.
Carissimus or Clarissimus puer, Civis publicus, Curavit ponendum.
Caius Rufus, Civis Romanus, Curavit reficiendum.
Dat, Dedit, &c., De, Decimus, Decius, Decretum, Decurio, Deus, Dicit, &c., Dies, Divus, Dominus, Domus, Donum.
Decurio coloniae, Diebus comitialibus, Divus Caesar.
Dea Dia, Decurionum decreto, Dedicavit, Deo dedit, Dono dedit.
Datum decreto decurionum, Dono dedit dedicavit.
Dedit imperator, Diis immortalibus, Diis inferis.
Deo invicto Mithrae, Diis inferis Manibus.
Deo Magno, Dignus memoria, Diis Manibus, Dolo malo.
Dedit proprio sumptu, Deo perpetuo sacrum, De pecunia sua.
Ejus, Eques, Erexit, Ergo, Est, Et, Etiam, Ex.
Fabius, Facere, Fecit, &c., Familia, Fastus (dies), Felix, Femina, Fides, Filius, Flamen, Fortuna, Frater, Fuit, Functus.
Faciendum curavit, Fidei commissum, Fiduciae causa.
Fidem dedit, Flamen Dialis, Fraude donavit.
Ferro flamma fame, Fortior fortuna fato.
Favete linguis, Fecit libens, Felix liber.
Gaius (=Caius), Gallia, Gaudium, Gellius, Gemina, Gens, Gesta, Gratia.
Gemina fidelis (applied to a legion). SoG. P. F. Gemina pia fidelis.
Habet, Heres, Hic, Homo, Honor, Hora.
Heres, Herennius. HER. and HERC. Hercules.
Hac lege, Hoc loco, Honesto loco.
Hoc monumentum, Honesta mulier, Hora mala.
Hic sepultus est, Hic situs est.
Haec urbs, Hic vivit, Honeste vixit, Honestus vir.
Immortalis, Imperator, In, Infra, Inter, Invictus, Ipse, Isis, Judex, Julius, Junius, Jupiter, Justus.
Julius Caesar, Juris Consultum, Jus civile.
Inferis diis, Jovi dedicatum, Jus dicendum, Jussu Dei.
Jacet hic, In honestatem, Justus homo.
In publico, Intra provinciam, Justa persona.
Kaeso, Caia, Calumnia, Caput, Carus, Castra.
Laelius, Legio, Lex, Libens, Liber, Libra, Locus, Lollius, Lucius, Ludus.
Laribus sacrum, Libens solvit, Locus sacer.
Magister, Magistratus, Magnus, Manes,' Marcus, Marius, Marti, Mater, Memoria, Mensis, Miles, Monumentum, Mortuus, Mucius, Mulier.
Magno Deo, Manibus diis, Matri deum, Merenti dedit.
Mala fides, Marci filius, Monumentum fecit.
Matri Idaeae, Matri Isidi, Maximo Jovi.
Manibus sacrum, Memoriae sacrum, Manu scriptum.
Municeps, or municipium; so also MN., MV., aud MVNIC.
Marti ultori sacrum, Merito votum solvit.
Natio, Natus, Nefastus (dies), Nepos, Neptunus, Nero, Nomen, Non, Nonae, Noster, Novus, Numen, Numerius, Numerus, Nummus.
Non licet, Non liquet, Non longe.
Nostri. NN., NNO., and NNR. Nostrorum.
Nobilis. NOB., NOBR., and NOV. Novembris.
Nefastus primo (i.e., priore parte diei), Non potest.
Ob, Officium, Omnis, Oportet, Optimus, Opus, Ossa.
Pars, Passus, Pater, Patronus, Pax, Perpetuus, Pes, Pius, Plebs, Pondo, Populus, Post, Posuit, Praeses, Praetor, Primus, Pro, Provincia, Publicus, Publius, Puer.
Pactum conventum, Patres conscripti, Pecunia constituta, Ponendum curavit, Post consulatum, Potestate censoria.
Pia fidelis, Pius felix, Promissa fides, Publii filius.
Piae memorise, Plus minus, Pontifex maximus.
Pater patratus, Pater patriae, Pecunia publica, Praepositus, Primipilus, Propraetor.
Pecunia sua, Plebiscitum, Proprio sumptu, Publicae saluti.
Pia victrix, Praefectus urbi, Praestantissimus vir.
Quaestor, Quando, Quantus, Que, Qui, Quinquennalis, Quintue, Quirites.
Quae infra scripta sunt; so Q. S. S. S. Quae supra, &c.
Recte, Res, Respublica, Retro, Rex, Ripa, Roma, Romanus, Rufus, Rursus.
Sacrum, Scriptus, Semis, Senatus, Sepultus, Servius, Servus, Sextus, Sibi, Sine, Situs, Solus, Solvit, Sub, Suus.
Sacrum diis, Salutem dicit, Senatus decreto, Sententiam dedit.
Sacrum diis Manibus, Sine dolo malo.
Sacerdos perpetua, Sine pecunia, Sua pecunia.
Si vales bene est, ego quidem valeo.
Terminus, Testamentum, Titus, Tribunus, Tu, Turma, Tutor.
Testamentum fecit, Titi filius, Titulum fecit, Titus Flavius.
Terminum posuit, Tribunicia potestate, Tribunus plebis.
Urbs, Usus, Uxor, Vale, Verba, Vestalis, Vester, Vir, Vivus, Vixit, Volo, Votum.
Vale conjux, Vir clarissimus, Vir consularis.
Verum etiam, Vir egregius, Visum est.
Usus fructus, Verba fecit, Vivus fecit.
Urbis praefectus, Vir perfectissimus, Vivus posuit.
Urbs Roma, Uti rogas, Votum reddidit.

table.head: II. MediaevalAbbreviations. —Of the different kinds of abbreviations in use in the middle ages, the following are examples:—

III. Abbreviations now in use. —The import of these will often be readily understood from the connection in which they occur. There is no occasion to explain here the common abbreviations used for Christian names, books of Scripture, months of the year, points of the compass, grammatical and mathematical terms, or familiar titles, like “Mr,” &c.
The ordinary abbreviations, now or recently in use, maybe conveniently classified under the following headings :—

row.cell: Associate of the Royal Scottish Academy
Companion of St Michael and St George.
Companion of the Star of India»

(Eboracensis), of York.
An archbishop or bishop, in writing his signature, substitutes for his surname the name of his see; thus the prelates of Canterbury, York, Oxford, London, &c., subscribe themselves A. C. Cantuar., W. Ebor., J. F. Oxon., J. London, &c.
Fellow of the Faculty of Physicians & Surgeons [Glasgow.]
Fellow of King and Queen’s College of Physicians in Ireland.
Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society.
Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians.
Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh.
Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons.
Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society.
Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh.
Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature.
Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries.
Knight Grand Cross of the Bath.
Knight Grand Cross of St Michael and St George.
Knight Grand Commander of the Star of India.
( JurisutriusqueDoctor), Doctor of Civil and Canon Law.
Knight Commander of the Star of India.
Licentiate of the Royal College of Physicians.
Licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons.
Member of the Royal College of Physicians.
Member of the Royal Irish Academy.
Solicitor before the Supreme Courts [of Scotland].
Writer to the Signet [in Scotland]. Equivalent to Attorney.

table.head:
2. Abbreviations denoting Monies, Weights, and Measures :—
Characters, not properly abbreviations, are used in the same way; e.g., ° ′ ″ for “degrees, minutes, seconds,” (circular measure); ℥, ℨ, ℈ for “ounces, drachms, scruples.” ℥ is probably to be traced to the written form of the z in “oz.”

row.cell:
L.,
These forms (as well as $, the symbol for the American dollar) are placed before their amounts. £, 2 or l.
(Anno Domini), In the year of our Lord.

Austriae est imperare orbi universo,
It is given to Austria to rule the whole earth. The device of Austria, first adopted by Frederick III.or Alles Erdreich Ist Oesterreich Unterthan.
(Aetatis[anno]), In the year of his age.
(AnnoHegiroe), In the year of the Hegira (the Mohammedan era).
(Anno Mundi), In the year of the world.
(Annourbisconditoe), In the year from the building of the city (i.e., Rome.)

cent.
“Per cent.” is often signified by %, a form traceable to “100.”
(Dei gratia), By the grace of God.
(Deo Optimo Maximo), To God the Best and Greatest.
(Etcaetera), And the rest; and so forth.
(Locus sigillj), The place of the seal.
(Per), For; e.g., ⅌ lb., For one pound.
(Quasi dicat), As if he should say; as much as to say.
(Quod erat demonstrandum), which was to be demonstrated.
(Quod erat faciendum), which was to be done.
(= r. for radix), the sign of the square root.
(Requiescatin pace ∕), May he rest in peace!
Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge.
seq. or sq., seqq. or sqq.
Society for the Propagation of the Gospel.
Christmas [This X is a Greek letter, corresponding to Ch.].

div.p: (See Graevius’s Thesaurus Antiquitatum, 1694, sqq.; Nicolai’s Tractatus deSiglis Veterum; Mommsen’s CorpusInscriptionum Latinarum, 1863, sqq.; Natalis de Wailly’s Paléographie, Paris, 1838; Alph. Chassant’s Paléographie, 1854, and Dictionnairedes Abréviations, 3d ed., 1866. A manual of the abbreviations in current use is a desideratum.)
